school_description: The student experience is highly personalized and differentiated across our three campuses. At Gateway to Holyoke Community College, the experience is a dual enrollment one, largely designed to preview the experience of a community college student with college level classes, and the independence and flexibility of college life. At Success Center, students are guided through a personalized Project-Based course of studies, supported by flexible scheduling and a primary person model that provides students with an advisor who knows them deeply and uses case conferencing to help them set and achieve goals. LightHouse Holyoke is a non-compulsory, extremely relevant and high-interest progressive school where students dictate their course of study, supported by an advisor, and take ownership over every aspect of their learning.
nominator: Center on Reinventing Public Education, Barr Foundation

school_description: Chelsea Opportunity Academy offers an engaging and supportive learning environment for young adults seeking a new educational experience.  At COA, every day is a new day. Our school is built on strong relationships that help us overcome obstacles and grow stronger. COA students develop and practice the specific skills they need to be successful, valued community members.

school_desc_other_text: We are public charter school within the KIPP network.
school_description: At KIPP Beyond Middle School, we believe that we are better together. In our increasingly diverse, but deeply divided city and country, we believe that there are no better people than our citys children to lead the way, and no better place to bring together children of different backgrounds than in school. A rigorous body of research has demonstrated the significant benefits to all students educated in racially and socioeconomically integrated settings, including higher academic achievement and higher academic growth; more critical and flexible thinking by being exposed to different perspectives; greater likelihood to enroll in college, report higher earnings, and demonstrate better long-term health outcomes; and increased empathy and reduced racial bias. KIPP Beyond incorporates engaging, rigorous, and relevant academics; a robust enrichment program; consistent physical conditioning; and a focus on identity, relationships, and belonging all informed by the research base on adolescent development.

Our model is grounded in four priorities that drive the student experience:  1. Social Emotional Learning: Scholars participate in relationship-based activities throughout the week, aimed at building skills, habits, and mindsets critical to their academic and personal development. This supports our highly inclusive atmosphere that centers belonging.  2. Personalized Instruction: Scholars receive individualized instruction designed to support, encourage, challenge, and motivate them. Students take ownership over their learning, and their daily experience adjusts based on their unique skills, interests, and academic goals.  3. Project Based Learning: Our schools use true-to-life projects to help build students leadership skills and innovative-thinking skills. Our project-based learning curriculum is designed to be affirming of students identities, directly relevant to their lives, and culturally responsive. In each project, scholars work collaboratively with their peers and actively engage within and around their communities.  4. Culture of Positivity: Our scholars PLAY BIG in a physically and emotionally inclusive environment. Scholars explore, take risks, build lasting friendships, and celebrate one another.
nominator: NewSchools Venture Fund, Center on Reinventing Public Education

Social Emotional Learning: Scholars participate in relationship-based activities throughout the week, aimed at building skills, habits, and mindsets critical to their academic and personal development. This supports our highly inclusive atmosphere that centers belonging.  2. Students take ownership over their learning, and their daily experience adjusts based on their unique skills, interests, and academic goals.  3. Our project-based learning curriculum is designed to be affirming of students identities, directly relevant to their lives, and culturally responsive. In each project, scholars work collaboratively with their peers and actively engage within and around their communities.  4. Culture of Positivity: Our scholars PLAY BIG in a physically and emotionally inclusive environment. Scholars explore, take risks, build lasting friendships, and celebrate one another.

URBAN ACT Academy uses a restorative framework to build a culture around shared values and community.  To prepare our students for an evolving global society, we incorporate a ""place-based"" approach where students learn skills and knowledge by studying the world they live in.  Our neighborhoods, communities and cities serve as a springboard for learning and investigation.  URBAN ACT students also benefit from personalized learning and targeted instructional practices that help us to understand what each student knows, what they need to know and how they learn best.

Our scholars learn through a blended Learning model.  This entails differentiation through station/playlist and the use of online curriculum.  Our scholars have the opportunity to move every 10 - 20 minutes depending on the grade level.  In the rotation there is always a teacher table where the educator pulls small groups to reach scholars at their learning level so that we can get maximum growth. We make sure that our we don't just grow our scholars academically but also through their social development.  We have Brotherhood circle with our entire campus every morning to celebrate our scholars and staff and then we say our Solar Pledge together.  Then the scholars go to their classes for thrive time which is an opportunity to build community in the classroom through messages, communication, and activities.

Rodriguez is a lever for San Marcos CISDs transformation of schools from traditional models into learning environments where students are empowered and motivated to reach mastery in highly personalized ways.  The instructional model of Rodriguez is reflective of the building itself, which is physically designed to facilitate future-ready learning. Driving pillars of the model include equity through personalized project-based learning, inclusion for all students, and justice through honoring and building upon the cultures, heritages, and family values represented in the student body. Rodriguezs intentional design is responsive to the unique needs and interests of each student with future-ready outcomes framing the instructional design.   There are four guiding pillars that drive Rodriguez Elementary that includes innovation, academic excellence, diversity, and community outreach. These guiding pillars help drive a  variety of programs designed to meet the strengths, needs, and interests of different student groups.

school_desc_other_text: PLA 103 is a traditional public charter school serving K-6 grade
school_description: The learning environment is designed to create a positive student experience through: * low student-teacher ratio * PBIS (Positive Behavior Intervention and Support) * rewarding high achievement and growth on weekly assessments * Reading Advantage Interventionists * Math Interventionists * 1-1 technology

Montessori Elementary @ Highland Park cultivates ambitious, fearless learners through intellectually-stimulating, interactive experiences that awakens curiosity, nurtures advanced thinking and promote independence while makng every effort to establish a trajectory for lifelong learning and self-directed discovery that enables children to reach their full potential as intellectually-engaged learners and ethically-focused leaders.

school_desc_other_text: We have an in-person and virtual program.  The majority of our students attend the in-person program, while less than 100 students attend the virtual program.
school_description: Our learning environment is designed to create student experiences based on our core areas of focus:  Centered on Students 	A learning community where every child experience success academically, socially and emotionally.   	A curriculum with the rigor and content that equips students to achieve the next step in their life goals/dreams. 	A strong partnership between the student, school and family that works towards common goals for student success.  	Students have the resources, tools and support to guide their development in a caring and nurturing environment.   	A team of dedicated educators and members that embrace their role as relationship builders.  Culture of Care 	A safe and secure school campus with an investment in the necessary equipment, training and drills to counter any potential risks.   	The appropriate programs and systems are in place to provide interventions for students academic, social and emotional needs. 	Teachers and all school team members receive the professional learning and growth in all areas related to the care of students and culture of school. 	The ASPIRA Con Cario approach is continuously refined and expanded to address the hierarchy of needs of students, families and team members.   	A school culture where diversity, equity, inclusion and belonging remain a focus and goal.  Communication 	Dual language instruction in K-12 to support pathway to biliteracy. 	An increase in the number and percentage of students earning the Delaware Certificate of Multiliteracy in 8th and 12th grade. 	A secondary track for biliteracy in middle school to support transition into high school. 	Students have real-life cultural experiences to strengthen biliteracy skills and cultural competency.    	A robust communication plan to keep school community, community partners and general public informed of LAAA progress and milestones.  Community 	A school community where Somos Familia is a shared sentiment among students, families and team members. 	Community engagement is maintained by seeking input, participation, feedback and support from students, families and team members on school matters to ensure different perspectives are considered in decisions. 	Family Resource Center services are adapted to support student learning and well-being by supporting the family unit with their hierarchy of needs. 	Community partnerships are secured to provide students, families and/or team members with opportunities for academic, social emotional or financial growth.   	Advocacy for students and public education by representing ASPIRA community in public, private and political sectors.
We prepare young women to use their voices, succeed in college, and lead impactful, meaningful lives.

school_desc_other_text: The High School of Commerce is one of several schools operating within and autonomous ""zone"" the Springfield Public Schools. As such, Commerce reflects the confluence of a ""hub"" of small learning community schools, all under the umbrella of the High School of Commerce, with each specializing in a niche area of pathways learning.
school_description: In examining sample wage data for graduates at the High School of Commerce from 2008 to 2013 (prior to the SEZP)for earnings five years after graduation show alumni income falling below twenty-five thousand dollars annually, about one-third less than the state average of their peers, 10% below Springfields average and the lowest average among Springfield high schools. As we work to develop smaller learning communities within the Commerce family of schools, we recognize the need to intentionally refocus efforts on this re-charting to ensure lucrative, high-growth careers that offer the greatest opportunity for our graduates.   To reimagine high school with graduate wage and career growth as the central mission, we are redesigning programs around the proven Early College model, where students take strategically sequenced college classes, with strong postsecondary and career orientation, accompanied by intensive academic and guidance support at no cost to students or families. Students will graduate from high school with significant college credits accrued, thereby reducing the financial burdens of college, maximizing time to explore, develop, and change college/career paths without financial penalty, and accessing intentional, personalized supports typically unavailable beyond high school that ensure persistence and postsecondary matriculation. Our personalized ""on-ramps"" and ""off-ramps"" allow students to customize a pathway and pacing that is malleable throughout their high school experience, allowing students to attain an Associate's degree (or 60-credit equivalent) by graduation, stackable career credentials, and choice among countless IHE partners and pathways aligned to the Pioneer Valley Labor Market Blueprint.

We are a diverse by design school that focuses on creating a learner driven environment. We do this by implementing restorative practices, social emotional learning, and project based learning. Our main goal is to provide rigorous instruction with deep social emotional integration.

The Red Lake Charter Schools aims to strengthen the Red Lake Nation by providing our children with an Ojibwe immersion education grounded in Ojibwe values that is academically rigorous and celebrates Indigenous culture. At the heart of Ojibwe culture is the connection between individuals and Mother Earth. The Red Lake Charter Schools aims to strengthen the Red Lake Nation by providing our children with an education grounded in Ojibwe values that is academically rigorous and celebrates Indigenous culture.   Anishinaabeg (Indigenous people) did not separate themselves from the land; our Mother Earth's connection is the umbilical cord to our existence. Indigenized education is the restoration of who we are to the places we call home. The intellectual framework will be constructed based on our relationship with the land, air, water, plants, and animals. We are firm believers in the Indigenous genius among our people. We will embrace our Indigenous resiliency through our educational platform.
Empower's personalized approach to teaching and learning energizes scholars to own their learning, develop social, emotional, and communication skills, and become leaders in their communities.

At Catalyst Public Schools, we believe that schools can be catalysts of community change when schools, families, and the larger community come together.  We also believe that each and every one of our scholars has unlimited potential and that they are the leaders of today and the champions of tomorrow.  Our mission is to support our diverse scholars to live full lives and to succeed in college, career, and life.  Scholars will find their purpose and passion so that they can cultivate the critical hope, optimism and leadership essential to be catalysts in their community and world.   Because of this, we intentionally create school environments that prepare our scholars to be leaders and change-makers.  Far too many schools prioritize compliance over engagement and rote memorization over critical thinking and collaboration.  At Catalyst, we are reimagining school to ensure our scholars are prepared for the future.   At Catalyst: Bremerton scholars develop the agency to lead their own learning alongside their peers.  We leverage a co-teaching model to offer small group and student lead instruction in grades from Kindergarten through 8th grade.  Hallmarks of the student experience at Catalyst: Bremerton include a daily class called Sunrise.  During Sunrise scholars explore the school's BRAVE values (Belonging, Resilience, Achievement, Vulnerability, and Enthusiasm) and participate in social emotional learning including mindfulness.  Another important element of our student experience is a course called Change Maker Space (CMS).  During CMS scholars participate in project based learning units that are aligned with our humanities courses of study and allow scholars to explore community challenges and work together to generate solutions.
Passion Power Agency Inclusion Community Connection / Relationships
Rigorous, grade level content; productive struggle; engaging student-centered content; student voice; accelerated learning; individualized learning; co-teaching model K-2.

Mission: Empower young people to live lives of their own design.   Vision: Happy Kids, Engaged in Healthy Relationships, on a Path to Gainful Employment.   Our Approach:   Signature design elements at all grade levels will serve as a catalyst for creating interest-based, authentic learning opportunities unique to each student. Design elements include:  Advisory  Often described as a second family by students, an advisory is a core organizational and relational structure that nurtures belonging. Learners stay with an advisor and a group of fellow classmates for multiple years, building close personal relationships that last a lifetime. Advisory experiences intentionally cultivate a learner-centered mindset by inspiring learners to develop the agency, skills, dispositions, and abilities needed to take charge of their learning journey. Advisors stand alongside students as they explore their passions and interests and help students turn challenges into learning opportunities.  Competency-based  Each student is a unique individual with knowledge, skills, and dispositions developed through learning experiences inside and outside school. Our competency-based system creates equitable learning structures and conditions that empower each student to meet rigorous, common expectations for learning through timely, differentiated support. Central to our approach is an intense focus on student growth through meaningful feedback and permission for them to show how they are progressing in many ways.  World of Work A national leader in early childhood career development, the Cajon Valley World of Work initiative engages students in hands-on experience right in their classrooms with a wide variety of careers, preparing them for their futures. World of Work uses each students interests, values, and strengths to tailor exploration, simulations, and virtual field trips with career professionals. Beginning in the Freshman year, all high school and post-secondary students will leverage early childhood interest exploration to identify and serve off-campus internships with highly qualified mentors. Local partners such as San Diego Workforce Partnership and Biocom are already playing a role in defining World of Work opportunities and engaging with our students.  Difference Making On-campus studio exploration empowers student entrepreneurs, makers, and inventors to impact their communities and world through their work and ideas. Students engage in community-based projects that tap their interests and strengths to make a meaningful difference in others lives. Their impact is amplified by our schools multilingual, multiliterate, and multicultural approach to learning. An example may include designing, building, and installing an equine sensory trail for children with autism.  Family Connection Accomplishing our vision challenges us to think differently about how we work together with students, families, and our community. Truly personalizing education beyond mere academic work involves looking at each student holistically. Families know their children best and they must play a proactive role in their childrens learning, collaborating in the planning and assessment of their students work.  Reimagining Postsecondary  Our goal is to push beyond dual and concurrent enrollment in community college to a coherent TK-14 experience, moving toward a strengths-based, truly personalized postsecondary experience that results in gainful employment opportunities in our immediate community. It is not our intent to partner with a community college to mirror or offer their program. Rather, create an integrated approach that builds on our World of Work initiative by extending internship and coursework beyond high school. Post high school students will maintain a relationship with an industry mentor and receive wrap-around services. Their Bostonia advisor, social worker, career counselor, and support staff will ensure an Associates degree and/or certificate of completion.

BELIEVEs mission, curriculum, teaching methods, services, and programming were carefully crafted and designed to meet the needs of the students we serv. With the goal of developing students into independent and influential citizens within their local and global communities, BELIEVE has intentionally designed supports and programming that meet the needs of our families and students.   Instruction & Curriculum Double Blocked ELA: Our double-blocked ELA sequence in 9th and 10th grade supports students by accelerating their completion of high school course credit requirements as well as remediating any learning gaps from students K-8 instruction, and creating more flexibility for career certification courses.  Gifted & Talented Accelerated Track: We recognize that while some students enter high school with significant learning gaps, others enter high school ready for greater challenges and having already earned some high school math credit. We support students who are ready for advanced learning by adjusting their schedules to enroll them in dual enrollment courses and higher level high school math courses as early as ninth grade. While many large high schools offer accelerated paths for gifted and talented students, BELIEVE provides a gifted and talented option within the attentive and close-knit setting of a small school.    Montessori Principles: In the Montessori model, the child directs their own learning pathway. BSTLA mirrors this in the Villages model that each student is a part of from the time they enroll at BELEIVE.   Individualized Learning Plan: Within a school community, the learning needs are as many and varied as the students. Although we believe that all students should have access to instruction that is informed by the principles of Universal Design for Learning (UDL), we also believe that all students should have access to high school learning pathways that best meet their individual needs and goals. At BELIEVE, we take a student-centered approach to scheduling, in alignment with our Child-Centered school value. Each students schedule is made by hand, and is informed by both qualitative and quantitative data.   Culture  BELIEVEs culture system is unique and truly one of a kind. As it was created and developed by the founding team and refined over the first two years of operation, expectation and culture systems are designed specifically for the students that we serve. Mirroring the standard corporate ladder, the Level Up System (LUS), was designed to provide students with real-world expectations and practices so they are prepared for life after college. The LUS was crafted to help students develop autonomy and agency so they can be self-sufficient, starters, and critical thinkers. This system, or the privileges accessed through it, are common in affluent neighborhoods and districts; however, not in black and brown communities. BELIEVE is changing that. The following are core pieces of our culture system that help support the whole child:   -Village Model -Social Emotional Learning -College, Community, and Career Programming
inclusive_other_text: We do not have any sutdents in the juvenile justice system

school_description: Our mission at Aventura Community School (ACS) is to elevate peace and justice by inspiring our diverse community to live as curious global citizens dedicated to changing the world.   The vision for achieving our mission is built around five key elements of our school model: -A bilingual learning environment with resulting cognitive, social, and cultural benefits -A project-based learning approach incorporating rigorous academics, 21st-Century skills, and social and emotional learning -A curriculum grounded in the Global Competence Framework -A connected and engaged diverse-by-design community -An inspiring professional culture where excellent teachers are supported and empowered to grow as professionals and individuals

Altura Prep is a joyful, learning-centered place where kids from all backgrounds come together to grow as people and as students. Prepsters learn the habits of mind and academic skills they need in order to be productive, engaged citizens AND empathetic, kind friends and neighbors. We celebrate one another's successes, and support one another through challenges.

school_name: Alabama Aerospace and Aviation High School
school_description: Our school is different by design, students are immersed in the robust nature of aviation and aerospace. The students are given unique opportunities that will support their social and emotional learning and the environment is catered to their needs. Students have a voice and a space to create, advocate and innovate. We say and believe that ""The Sky Is No Longer the Limit.""

school_desc_other_text: Innovation Lab High School is an option school within the Northshore School District.
school_description: Innovation Lab High School borrows heavily from the Expeditionary Learning (EL) model, placing a focus on community-building and interdisciplinary project-based learning.  To that powerful model, we have added key elements of Culturally Responsive and Sustaining Education and Mastery-Based Learning.  Our ultimate goal is to empower students with the skills to build a future worth fighting for.  As such, student voice is strongly encouraged, and student leadership is intentionally fostered.

The LightHouse educational experience goes well beyond conventional practices and offers a personalized approach for young people aged 13 and older. We are supporting students to do much more than get by or get through it, but to thrive.   LightHouse is a competency-based program, meaning we value learning and individual development over seat-time or arbitrary curriculum. We change the teacher-student relationship entirely to create a truly collaborative process that is founded in trust and mutual respect.
nominator: Mastery Transcript Consortium, Center on Reinventing Public Education

school_description: Established in 2019, Windham Woods is a small, private school in southern New Hampshire serving 160 young people from grades 1-12, who experience mild to moderate learning challenges. At Windham Woods we believe confidence is the root of success. To promote confidence and growth in each of our young learners, we celebrate differences and tailor our program, and the myriad supports available, to meet the needs of each individual learner. We build skills and confidence simultaneously, each supporting the other.  All classes emphasize skills that will allow students to succeed across academic areas and in the real world, including: self-advocacy, organization, time management, longterm planning, and communication. Students at Windham Woods develop confidence in themselves and their learning process, as well as how to succeed independently and collaboratively. Class sizes are capped at 10 students, giving all upper schoolers the ability to form strong, supportive, and meaningful relationships with their peers and teachers. Due to our small size and faculty-student ratio, we are able to provide students with an academic program that adjusts to their individual needs, whether that means adjusting class sizes, remediation, accelerated courses and content, or individual time with any of our full- or part-time specialists (reading, counseling, speech & language, occupational therapy, etc).

At Bennett Day School, our mission is to provide a collaborative culture that nurtures our innate sense of inquiry and curiosity. We are committed to advancing creativity, innovation, and the development of lifelong learners and leaders.
contact_role: Founding Upper School Director and Head of Program
respondent_role: Founding Upper School Director and Head of Program

school_description: Ruby Bridges Elementary is a fully inclusive school community centering on our commitment to each student: YOU ARE A LEARNER. YOU ARE A LEADER. YOU BELONG HERE. We are a school community focused on creating the conditions for our students to experience all of the dimensions of belonging in a supportive, universally designed learning environment.   We utilize inclusionary principles and practices to bring this vision to life including: * Inclusive Mission and Vision * Universal Design for Learning  * Flexible Service Delivery * Core Master Schedule * Collaborative Planning * Co-Teaching  Our work to ensure learning, leading and belonging for each member of our community is grounded in a belief in the competence and potential of each student as a member of the general education classroom when given supportive, relevant and universally design learning experiences. Students experience the full range of learning supports and extensions as members of their classroom community and as a school community, we actively work to disrupt injustice in all forms. Our students experience community learning with learner variability is the constant and the development of understanding of self, learner attributes and the tools for learning best is just a part of each and every school day. As our students experience learning in community they are encouraged to welcome differences, to explore how they learn best and are given the necessary support to thrive.  The Ruby Bridges Elementary community and culture is often described a special in its positivity, warmth and the genuine feeling of possibility brimming from each classroom. Our school is a family of diverse members, each coming with unique backgrounds and experiences, and our goal each day is to amplify the strengths of our community and affirm our students along their pathway in elementary school. We believe that students who learn together learn how to live together.

Creative Minds International PCS is the only public school in DC that offers accredited International Early Years, Primary, and Middle Years Curricula. We also offer a diverse curriculum with project- and arts-based activities. Our goal is to provide students with the foundational skills required for successful participation in a global society.

Antrim Elementary provides a safe and inclusive environment where children are challenged to take academic risks. Students' learning experiences include a rich mix of instruction designed through a Universal Design for Learning lens.  The school uses the Responsive Classroom approach in developing and teaching social skills.  This approach helps teachers establish a calm and safe classroom while helping children develop self-discipline and a sense of community and responsibility.

Fenway is an early college high school with more than 40 years of experience educating Boston youth. We are proud of our national reputation and many awards for innovation and excellence. Our students and faculty teach and learn together in a diverse, respectful community.  Founded in 1983, Fenway became one of Bostons six original pilot schools in 1994. Fenway is devoted to providing a high-quality, personalized education to students from all over the city of Boston. Our proven success is largely due to our established set of teaching practices and school structures based on three core principles:  intellectual challenge personalized relationships early college & collaborations with universities

Tapestry is designed to break away from the traditional one-size-fits-all approach to education. We dont believe in classifying students as either general education or special education. Instead, Tapestry recognizes and celebrates the diverse learning profiles and needs of all of our students. Our model is simple: we value all of our students for their uniqueness and believe that each one deserves to feel included in all aspects of the learning process. Tapestrys fully inclusive academic model supports this belief and creates a platform for all of our students to succeed.
The BLPS learning environment vision is to empower learners to set goals that engage and demonstrate mastery at a pace that fits their needs with rigor and support.
focus_other_text: We do not have any students from the juvenille justice system due to the age of students served at BLPS.

school_description: We believe that natural learning at any age requires a large amount of dedicated time to experience, explore, play, interact, and converse. Our programming ensures that this free time (as many adults call it) for natural learning is protected. On top of this basic tenant of self-directed education, we build a variety of  practices that encourage:      * intentional learning      * social/emotional growth      * social justice awareness      * active engagement in the creation of the school's culture      * development of reflective capacities

I Dream Public Charter School's learner-centered, strengths-based approach is a collaboration between the learner, staff, and the family, and incorporates the assets of the community into instruction and learning. We achieve this approach in four powerful ways:  1. Joyfully Rigorous Learning. I Dream PCS learners learn how to learn. They engage in learning that makes them think deeply and delve into challenging text and math problems like detectives. They experiment, write, problem-solve, and research independently and with their peers and adults (called coaches instead of teachers) to learn Common Core State Standards and to answer their questions about themselves and the world around them. Its the challenges that make them grow and learn who they are.  2. Dream Time. I Dream PCS learners have weekly Dream Time to identify and explore a curiosity or interest they want to learn about. Curiosity breeds deep learning and innovation. Coaches working with learners conference with and observe them in Dream Time to document the skills learners use in their deep learning and to guide them to transfer the skills and knowledge to their academic learning, or apply the Common Core State Standards they learn in academic classes in Dream Time.   3. Social-Emotional Learning. Research shows that learners who engage in social-emotional learning demonstrate better academic performance, positive attitudes and reduced stress. I Dream PCS learners meet daily in Community Time with their coaches and classmates to develop their emotional intelligence and healthy relationships with themselves and others.  4. Customized learning. A Customized Learning Plan (CLP) is a living document created with each learner, their family and coaches to identify learning targets and action steps towards mastery of math, literacy, social-emotional learning, and dreamer goals. CLPs are a learner-centered assessment practice to build ownership of learning through continuous goal-setting, reflection and mastery of standards. I Dream PCS learners understand what they have learned and communicate why they learned it, and demonstrate progress and achievement of CLP goals.
grades_other_text: I Dream PCS will serve PK-5th grades in SY23-24.

school_description: '- experiential learning inside and outside of the classroom - SEL competencies embedded into various programmatic elements  - community-based experiences aligned to curriculum - celebrations of learning designed for students to share their learning and public products - project-based learning

school_desc_other_text: Dual language immersion school (offering Mandarin Chinese and Spanish pathways)
school_description: Global Citizens is the first dual language immersion elementary school in Washington, DC, to offer language immersion in both Mandarin Chinese and Spanish pathways - exposing students to the top three languages spoken in the world.  Paired with a focus on social justice and whole child wellness, Global Citizens equips children to become empathetic, globally competent, and socially-minded leaders who are prepared for a future we cannot yet imagine.  Global Citizens opened in Ward 7 to provide children and their families living east of the Anacostia River with equitable access to dual language immersion programs.  The mission of Global Citizens PCS is to inspire and prepare the next generation of global citizens.  We will do this by supporting students, ages 3-11, to reach their full academic and leadership potential in a nurturing learning environment.  We will immerse them in the Mandarin and Spanish languages, promote the value of diversity, and equip them with the knowledge, skills, and mindsets they need to contribute to a better world.  We envision academic excellence, language acquisition, and authentic inclusion of a diverse student population.  We will build a strong community of learners who are confident in their ability to communicate in the Chinese, Spanish, and English languages.  Our children will use language to liberate and advocate for themselves and those most marginalized.  All of our children will develop a sense of self and a sense of belonging, build empathy and emotional resilience, learn to understand and appreciate diverse perspectives, and challenge themselves to take action to improve the world.

Capitol Learning Academy individualizes each student's learning plan according to interest and ability. We move at a pace that works for student subject mastery across not just each subject, but each topic, and can always circle back to revisit topics from previous years if refreshers are needed. There is no pressure of whole class instruction or scheduling, nor the risk of boredom if something is moving too slow and a student already ""gets it."" Additionally, time is set aside each day for students to work in multi-age cooperative groups, to research, discuss, and present to their peers about a variety of social studies or science topics. With students coming from different socio-economic backgrounds, neighborhoods and types of families, the perspectives that come into the group conversations cause rich conversations and a broader understanding of the larger world. Finally, we go beyond our four walls and utilize our local city community daily, through playing at a public park for recess, checking out books at our local library, to partnering with local organizations and businesses for our daily subject specialist classes (PE, Music, Art, etc). Students are comfortable in, and appreciate their community and what it can provide for them and their families.

Everything we do at One World Middle School is an experience in supporting our students to achieve and to become an Ambassador of Change.  At OWMS our ambassadors commit to taking full ownership of their  learning through discovery and exploration.   Ambassadors will develop their skills, knowledge, motivation, and curiosity to become confident learners who are fully invested in their learning.  We want to inspire life-long learners who will give back to the community.  If we commit to fostering student center approach and methodology that is rooted in discovery and exploration then ambassadors will develop their skills, knowledge, motivation, and curiosity to initiate their own learning and become reflective learners thus gaining full ownership and autonomy of their education to make impactful changes in their community.

* Emphasis on school, class and student level goal setting, utilizing benchmark, online program and classroom assessment data.  * Creating a community culture where students are empowered to take ownership of their growth and achievement.  * Implementation of student data portfolios and student led conferences in grades 3-8.   * Whole school daily morning gathering including prayer, song, scripture, St. Patrick Star awards, dance and mission.  * Math plus program for grades 3 through 8 providing differentiated, small group, additional math instruction weekly.  * Resource and gifted opportunities available to eligible students kindergarten through grade 8.  * Small group differentiated reading instruction daily in kindergarten through grade 5.  * Middle school electives and specialized programs including kayaking, gardening, media arts, band, team sports and STEM.  * After school enrichment opportunities for kindergarten through grade 8 including sports, STEM, drama, Odyssey of the Mind and art.

The student experience at Ross Elementary revolves around fostering a growth mindset for all stakeholders. The staff at Ross are committed to creating, maintaining, and continually working to improve the school community and culture to raise student achievement. Teachers at Ross Elementary take pride in being a community of learners who believe that continuous learning in their craft will lead to developing rigorous lessons. Data is used to drive instruction, while teachers set high expectations, take risks, and build student leaders to create a school culture where students are afforded a positive environment to grow academically, socially, and emotionally.

At David H. Petree Elementary we engage students, families, and teachers in the implementation of high expectations and action-oriented strategies that produce deliberate change to improve student achievement and success for our school through Literacy and STEM Education.  * Opportunity Culture Initiatives * Student Engagement with Hands-On Science/STEM Instruction * Strategic and Aligned Data Driven Instruction * Restorative Practices/SEL/PBIS * Community and Family Engagement

The student experience that the learning environment is designed to create at Lucama Elementary school incorporates:  -Grades K-5 implementing The Science of Reading -Grades 2nd - 5th implementing Learning Focused Instructional Framework -Grades K -5 implementing The CRA Model in mathematics -Grades K-5 implementing targeted small group instruction with the supports of Opportunity Culture staffing, in both reading and mathematics -Grades 3-5 providing extending learning opportunities for specific subgroups of students. -Grades K-5 interventionist and tutors supporting Tier II and Tier III students
'- Culturally Relvant - hands on math - inquiry science - project based social studies -community based - filled with love

Our mission is for ecxellence and equity in a climate of respect, responsibility, and pride. Our school strives for this by cultivating strong healthy relationships. We believe we have as strong culture at CHS, and recognize not all students feel and experience that the same way. We continue to reflect on our practices and policies to improve our learning experience for all.

We are working to create an environment based on equity and agency.  This includes keeping students at the center of all decision-making, actively developing anti-biased policies, and including student voice in decision-making.  We use responsive and restorative practices and focus on competency-based personalized learning in order to support students in the development of their academic and social agency.
grades_other_text: We currently only have 6th and 7th graders; 8th will be added next year.

school_description: At PHS, we work to change the learning environment to focus on individual needs and programs centered around the desired state of learning for students.

Over the past 2 years, our students have suffered from the inability to have access to the classroom on a regular basis due to COVID.  As we are looking at NWEA testing, State testing, and overall school performance we are seeing a separation in our student body.  We have a group of students who are at grade level and doing fine. We also have a group of students that have greatly declined in student performance compared to previous years.   We want to help correct that.  Our goal with this program is to bring kids back up to grade level as well as push kids above and beyond the classroom.  For the students that are at grade level or above, we want to challenge those students to continue to push forward.  We have a lot of students that can push themselves further than we have pushed in the past in the educational setting. This, Beyond the Classroom program, will focus on both ends of the spectrum.
focus_other_text: We include all students no matter the ""group"" that people outside of education put them in.
inclusive_other_text: All student groups are fully integrated into all classrooms and courses offered.

school_desc_other_text: Hamilton Community Schools also has its traditional K-12 school
school_description: Hamilton High School is a traditional daily, seated, daily attendance school that has a large population of students that attend the Careerline Tech Center. Several students choose to take online courses during the day. Hamilton High School also offers a variety of AP and dual enrollment courses.

At Portland Middle School we have made several adjustments and changes to the 6th grade structure. This has provided a more structured and supportive transition from elementary school to middle school. It is our goal at Portland Middle School for students to understand what their purpose is and to find it in the moments they have within their time at our school.

school_district: State Charter School (physically located in DeKalb County)
school_desc_other_text: We are a tuition-free, public Kindergarten-8th grade South DeKalb charter school enrolling grades K-3 in 2023 (adding a grade each year).  Together with hundreds of families and community members, we have designed a school that empowers students to be leaders in any field they choose. Our school combines college-preparatory academics, social-emotional learning, and an innovative focus on real-world, career-connected projects.  We put all of this together through our Real-world Project-based Learning, where students learn not only from their teachers and peers, but also directly from scientists, lawyers, engineers, and designers.
school_description: '- Honoring Identities: Our school honors students' identities and creates the predictable, safe learning environment students need to grow into their leadership. - Exceptional Teaching: We honor our teachers as professionals with high-quality teaching materials and significant time for collaborative planning and learning from each other. - Collaborative Partnerships: We treat our families and community as the valuable experts they are, and strengthen our school through early, frequent, and thorough partnerships. - Building Leadership: Through goal setting, reflection, and intentional skill development, teachers and students engage in the skills we need to collaborate and lead. - Rigor & Relevance: Our students have rich, complex experiences in humanities, math, and science to empower them to be critical thinkers and creative problem solvers. - Real-world Projects: Our teachers partner with community experts to create real-world learning. The same experts coach teams of students and are in the audience to celebrate students' work at the end of each semester.

The tenets of Valor Prep are: 1) High Level Relationship Building 2) High Level in-class activities that apply the knowledge from the online 3) High Level Tutoring that is driven by the relationships and formative data from #1 and 2.   4) Empower all aspects of the school, student, parents, teachers, admin, etc to make the educational decisions that best fit the need.   Valor is a hybrid school, so that means we let an online program with lots of formative data set the floor(foundation) and the teachers who are with the student set the ceiling.  For the students, they will feel empowered to apply learning in the the classrooms and out of school with teachers who have demonstrated a connection to their lives.  Students will develop the self-advocacy and agency to choose how much help or structure they want outside of class time.     To do this use an instructional model that is color coded with blue and red connected as hexagons resembling a beehive to show interdependence.  The Red is what online does for the students, families, teachers, admin and blue is what the humans bring to the experience.  This is an essential step because a good hybrid plan must have that well described and delineated so our amazing teachers arent do what a course management system with good formative assessments can do.

Roxbury Roots Montessori, Inc. seeks to offer an affordable, child-centered, authentic, high-quality, African-centered, Montessori program in Roxbury--an historically underserved community.  Roxbury Roots Montessori, Inc. is a member of the Wildflower Schools Network, serving children aged 2.9 through 6-years-old. Our school is unique, in that we offer an African-centered curriculum based within the Montessori pedagogy. Our vision is to bring high-quality, affordable, Montessori education to the Greater Boston area. As a community-based program, we aim to work closely with parents, Roxbury community members, and the Wildflower network to expose children to languages and positive images of peoples from the Black diaspora, thus instilling a sense of pride and empowerment in our students.

At Prospect, our learning environment aims to be as personalized and supportive as possible.  Students experience success and build off that success to create a new narrative about their learning.  We group students by skill level in reading, writing, and math, which helps them learn at their current level and gives them confidence that they can learn.  We empower students to analyze their own data and learning trajectories using Precision Teaching, and this also helps us ensure essential skills are learned with fluency, not just accuracy.  We regularly check progress through use of Curriculum-Based Measurements, which is another celebration of student growth - and growth is a big focus for us.    Additionally, we have a dedicated movement block and social-emotional learning time each day, and our goal is for the concepts from these classes to be integrated into academic classes across the day.  These classes equip our learners with other skills that are essential for success.

Goshen Post continues to be a strong academic school providing authentic learning experiences through a Project Based Learning framework. Through the PBL process, students not only excel in academia but also 21st century competencies. Collaboration, Creative Thinking, and Problem Solving are essential elements for the Goshen Post Student. Through authentic learning experiences, students are provided with purposeful learning opportunities.

school_name: STREAM School at Hamilton Middle School
school_description: What is STREAM School?  STREAM School at Hamilton Middle School is an important collaboration between Hamilton Community Schools,  the Outdoor Discovery Center in Holland and other partners in the greater Holland area.  The program is designed to provide meaningful access to valuable resources in West Michigan such as Lake Michigan, dunes, wetlands, and the Outdoor Discovery Center property. The experiences are not field trips, rather an extension of the classroom and hopefully unforgettable moments that keep students engaged in the area.  Who is involved in Hamilton Middle School?  We offer STREAM School for 1 semester to every 8th Grade student. Our Hamilton STREAM Team is comprised of the following staff members:  Teachers Steve Hickok and Mitchell Niewoonder Career and Experience Coordinator, Ashley Meyer Instructional Coach, Christine Martin The focus is purposeful experiences outside of the classroom and connecting students to the Career Pathway of Agriscience and Natural Resources while learning English standards and Science Standards.

The learning environment is designed to support scholars with being critical thinkers. Critically analyzing situations from diverse perspectives and making their realizations for themselves. Supporting scholars in understanding how to reflect on where others are, and how that may affect them. We want scholars to be comfortable addressing and discussing racism and oppression.  Scholars should be affirmed and have suave to see their own brilliance and ancestral brilliance, recognizing truths vs myths in those histories.

Phoenix International Academy partners with families and communities to provide powerful learning experiences that unleash students natural ability for creativity, innovation, collaboration and social responsibility. We take the time to figure out each childs strengths and areas for growth, and tailor learning to their specific needs. Students learn through working on projects, which are driven by their interests and academic needs. Through these projects, students develop the academic and social emotional competencies to complete higher education, thrive in the future of work, and create positive change in their communities and the world.

La Promesa provides students new to the country global, career, and academic competencies needed to decide their future path as high school graduates. Students acquire language in an environment that addresses their individual academic and social emotional needs. At La Promesa, students: - Embrace and strengthen their biliteracy - Develop social awareness through culture and diversity - Receive intensive language and academic support - Work towards college and career readiness

school_district: State Charter Schools Ii- Georgia Fugees Academy Charter Sc
school_desc_other_text: We serve refugee and new American students.
school_description: Georgia Fugees Academy Charter School is a place where students want to be. It is a rigorous and supportive academic community where students have fun working hard. The ongoing support from our team helps every Fugees student strengthen their socio-emotional skills and build a strong network so they feel prepared to navigate a new culture.

Atlas is designed for joyful and authentic learning. Students are exposed to a rigorous curriculum that integrates meaningful, real-world experiences. Students are known, loved, and given the specific supports and challenges they need to thrive.

We are a true equity project, opening in 2014 as a new hope and opportunity for our neighborhood. Our first engagement is engagement for all students, ensuring that their hearts are stoked as well as their minds!

school_desc_other_text: We have had some challenges the past six months and now offer additional support to most of our learners through after school programming. We are in the process of collaborating with community partners to re-imagine our approach and identifying resources and additional partners to help to work toward our vision.
school_description: Learners understand that ""We are Indigenous first--Lakota first. We cannot go home and take it off because it is in our DNA."" OSELC uses this lens--the foundation of who we are--in our educational approach. We seek to cultivate and strengthen learners' (and our) cultural identities by validating Lakota knowledge using Lakota thought and philosophy as the reference point. Learners know they belong because we model how to be a good relative and that we are part of a collective reclaiming how we educate ourselves and our children. We nurture and harness curiosity and student inquiry, using their observations as a roadmap to know where to go and what to build upon the next day.
The learning environment is designed to create curious students who are excited to expand their knowledge and who instinctively desires to research unknown topics.

We do not believe that students should sit at desks and chairs!  Instead, students at La Luz are out, learning in the community, 80% of every school day.  We partner with amazing organizations, such as The Denver Zoo or History Colorado to co-create a 6-week learning experience.  Yep, kids go everyday for 6-weeks to the zoo, or a museum, or any other great community partner.  Additionally, we spend a ton of time outdoors, in nature.  At least 20% of our year will be spent in nature, whether that is hiking, building snow caves, carving sticks or starting fires, we know just how critical being outside in nature is to our wellbeing.
inclusive_other_text: Homeschool and traditional learners  are integrated

school_description: Learning at 8MS is grounded in building skills for employment and social-emotional support. As an intentionally small school, we create personalized plans and offer one-to-one support for each student to fuel their personal and academic growth. Rather than forcing young people to choose between school and work, 8MS consolidated instruction and enrichment into the morning so students are able to work in the afternoon, gaining exposure to workforce training, employment opportunities, and income.
grades_other_text: We have a mixture of students that are at-risk of dropping out and have dropped out of traditional public schools.

school_description: Serving primarily African American students, autonomy has allowed us to institute the successful values and methods implemented after Reconstruction that created, by the year 1900, a virtually non-existent illiteracy rate among African-Americans under the age of 40. We do this by emphasizing math, English, character-building, and hands-on activities that are easily transferable to technical careers. Our core belief is that technical careers have the potential to help our students escape poverty by attaining sustainable wages.

Our purpose is to provide a nurturing and safe school climate by building positive relationships, resulting in high academic and social achievement for ALL students. We prepare our students to become productive, lifelong learners, and responsible citizens. Our values are:  *Respect *Integrity *Collaboration *Perseverance *Growth Mindset *Hard Work *Accountability *Communication *Teamwork *Positive Relationships
nominator: Center for the Future of Arizona

school_description: Students learn to work independently and to set their own learning goals and pathways.  They assume more responsibility for their progress than in a traditional school setting.  The self-paced nature of the program allows students to progress more quickly if they choose.  The academic program is rigorous and reading- and writing-intensive, leading to development of essential college and career readiness skills.  Students enjoy opportunities to participate in their education from anywhere, at anytime.

school_desc_other_text: We are both a school and service provider for schools in AZ and nationally/internationally
school_description: ASU Prep Digitals educational model integrates the K-12 and university experience to acclimate students to a college mindset and community and to accelerate time to degree. Courses are designed to give students choice and pace options. Students routinely interact with highly qualified instructors and have personal learning success coaches who ensure they make progress toward their academic and career goals. ASU Prep Digital strategically opens ASUs catalog of college courses to allow students to explore and earn course credit in future college majors and careers as they are ready. The entire learning experience is designed to grow student agency, choice, and strength in learning to navigate their own educational journey.

school_name: North Florida School of Special Education
school_desc_other_text: We function as a private independant school for students with Intellectual and Developmental differences ages 6 - 22 years of age.
school_description: Classrooms are designed from a therapeutic perspective with muted lighting, sensory supports, small group instruction and differentiated learning. Academics are integrated with social skills, art, music, P.E., garden and barn classes including caring for our four horses, pigs, chickens and rabbit. Independence, life skills and vocational skills are emphasized at all grade levels with a direct focus during Transition years 18-22. North Florida School of Special Education is a frontrunner in the field of Reverse Inclusion, a technique in which typical students and adults visit our school and are immersed in our special education classrooms. The purpose of Reverse Inclusion is to create a comfortable environment in which our students are able to interact successfully with their typical peers and appropriate role models.
focus_other_text: North Florida School of Special Education serves students with intellectual and developmental differences between the ages of 6-22, and also offers a Postgraduate program for young adults between the ages of 22-40. NFSSE adheres to a 1:6 Teacher to Student ratio, and offers six levels of instruction within eleven classrooms.

school_description: The student feels safe, cared for, relaxed, supported and has the freedom to fail and learn from mistakes.  Students feel accepted and free to have a bad day/moment and still be made to feel worthy and validated as a human being.
nominator: Transcend, Center on Reinventing Public Education

school_desc_other_text: I'm not sure if we would be considered a micro school. We currently serve 66 students grades 5-12 and will grow to 100-140 students. We're an independent private school who serves students who learn differently. We follow a Mastery-based learning model which includes differentiated instruction, and individualized learning, and student choice, We teach social-emotional skills and executive functioning skills alongside academic skills.
school_description: We want to help students identify and remove any barriers to their learning, so that they can be present in the classroom and open to learning. We want students to feel safe, develop positive relationships with staff and students, and enjoy learning.  Our goal is to develop independent life longer learners who can identify their strengths, self-advocate, apply what they've learned to our larger world.

school_desc_other_text: Big Picture Learning school - Students attend school and internships for learning
school_description: Through Big Picture Learning, Swiftwater staff hopes to  create  a learning environment that fosters the  needs and interests of each student. In doing this, we hope to  instill a passion for learning, working, and service that will that will continue to follow students once they graduate from our program.  Big Picture Learning (BPL) puts students at the center of their education experience. This model of learning allows students to work closely with their advisor (teacher) to identify interests and  personalize learning.  Through Big Picture Learning, students will improve academic skills as well as participate in real world learning.  In BPL, learning is demonstrated through internships, crash labs, projects, portfolios, and exhibitions.
inclusive_other_text: Students who identify as LGBTQ  In general for all group types - we are a very small school, so may not have any or all of the above listed students at any given time.  However, we have had the listed student groups on occasion.

school_desc_other_text: Intergenerational learning community; Day School for teens ages 13-18
school_description: I believe the learners sum it up best:   I would not be who or where I am today without Springhouse. Here, I am not a grade or a label; I am seen and valued as the whole person that I am, with all that comes with it.  Tati Springhouse Day School Graduate 2022
grades_other_text: We have an adult program that partially integrates with our teen Day School
inclusive_other_text: Our school includes learners of diverse backgrounds, including being previously involved in the juvenile justice system, being born outside of the United States, and being a part of the LGBTQIA+ community (nearly half of our learners identify as a part of this community).

school_description: The learning environment is designed to create a sense of belonging for each and every student.  The work of our faculty and staff in meeting our students where they are academically and helping them to make progress no matter where they start is our priority and focus.  Grayson High School strives to add value to a child's education from year to year causing students to make academic gains in the four core discipline areas of Math, Science, Language Arts, and Social Studies.  Students are provided academic opportunities in a variety of course selections, including Advanced Placement, Modern Classical Languages, STEAM (science, technology, engineering, arts, and math), Dual Enrollment, and Gifted and Talented.  In addition to the focus on the four core areas, our students explore careers beyond the classroom through the Grayson Technical Educational Program.  Students may select from a variety of programs such as; Digital Media, Veterinarian, Culinary Arts, and Photography.  The plethora of course selections and hands-on learning experiences allows our students to foster their sense of belonging within our school culture.

At Phoenix Modern, learners begin a journey of discovery and growth in a tight-knit community. They form community with their peers as they begin to take on responsibility for their own learning and how to care for others. Learners are inspired and equipped to advance in core skills while also facing opportunities to explore and create in a variety of topics. Throughout their experience, learners grow in their self-awareness and awareness of others, as well as their in their ability to solve problems and use resources to accomplish goals.

Our project-based approach with a narrative format allows for the learners to apply knowledge across subjects and disciplines allowing for deeper learning and understanding.  The daily learning objective is for each student to learn how to learn, learn how to do and learn how to be. Through personal empowerment, agency, and responsibility, character growth drives our curriculum with students taking charge of managing and governing their own learning path and school community. Each graduate will be equipped to lead an organization, create curriculum, and inspire others to follow a Heros Journey.

Clark Street Community School seeks create a learning environment where every child knows they belong, deeply understands their personal genius and confidently understands how they can use it for the greater good.
focus_other_text: Students who identify as LGBTQ+ Yes.  Definitely

school_description: A space that nurtures unique identity development, creates space for deep reflexivity through thought-provoking project discoveries, and cultivates the individualized strengths of learners resulting in a culture of rich collaboration without unnecessary competition.
We aspire to be an equitable community of learners who encourage excellence and honor growth. The environment is designed to create an experience that is empowering and independent.
We believe every learner can change the world; therefore, we will provide a world class education.

school_name: CLK Engage at CLK Elementary School
school_district: Public Schools Of Calumet Laurium Keweenaw
school_description: The learning environment is designed to create and build positive relationships between students, school staff, parents and community members.  Staff and students greet each other alike.  Ask Me About signs hang outside of each classroom with three topics to encourage conversations.  Social contracts are developed as a group and signed by both students and staff. Positive relationships is key to the success of all programs and stakeholders.  The CLK Engage program is designed to create a learning environment where teachers are shared.  Students and staff begin their day by having all three classes come together for Morning Meeting.  Inspirational quotes and character lessons are incorporated in the Morning Meeting to inspire, motivate and teach positive behavior expectations before launching the students into their language arts groups.  After lunch and recess, the students are also launched into their math groups.  At the end of the day, all of the students and staff come together again to celebrate good things for what they call launch.  Morning Meeting and Launch provide opportunities for all students to come together to build positive relationships with all three teachers.  CLK Engage has also implemented Fun Fridays.  At the end of the day on Friday, students have the opportunity to choose the classroom they would like to spend their time based on the activity the teacher is offering.  Parents and community members also provide additional support to offer additional choices to students as well.  The idea behind Fun Fridays is to provide students more voice and choice with their learning based on their individual interests.

All students need to have hope that they will reach their goals. In a supportive learning environment, they learn that effort and momentum are celebrated and that the people truly care about them and their struggles. Our students know that they are cherished and we believe in their success.

A Crossroads FLEX student is responsible, self-motivated, engaged, and exhibits the highest degree of integrity. Students are encouraged to reflect on the world around them, refocus their priorities, and refine what they are willing to try differently. Students engage in leadership opportunities through providing services to nonprofit organizations, internships, and partnerships with local businesses to assist with problem-solving. At Crossroads FLEX, students attend school on a flexible schedule with time built in to meet face-to-face with teachers to review their learning progress, discuss their work, ask questions, or receive assistance with difficult concepts. Students work independently on online lessons, projects, and assignments at home and school. Crossroads FLEXs vision is to guide and graduate students whose individual pursuits empower them to emblazon change upon the world.

school_district: Steamboat Springs School District NO. Re 2
school_description: Learning is relevant for students as it focuses on project based learning, skill based needs for individual students, and career connected learning. Students are empowered to find their own learning path with the support provided by teachers, counselor, and administrator.  Healthy relationships within the school help to build students' confidence to explore their identifies and interests.

Our learners are developing a mindset approach to learning, collaboration, and problem solving. Our teachers walk student through a structured framework for identifying challenges, gathering information, generating potential solutions, refining ideas, and testing solutions.

Our long-term vision is to support our students in thinking computationally--enhancing their ability to both think through and solve problems. We are looking to change the way our students think and learn by planning for instruction that requires them to personally interact and connect with the curriculum; seeing and making their own connections among concepts.  Our goal is to create a robust curriculum filled with challenging real-world tasks, independent and paired student exploration, rich academic discussion, and high student (self and peer) expectations.  It is within these tasks that students are breaking down (decomposing)ideas, looking for and recognizing patterns, creating generalizations for solving the current and similar tasks in the future, and finally recognizing or discovering the steps or rules to solve the task.

school_desc_other_text: We are a companion school that offers innovative programming and classes to our comprehensive high schools.
school_description: Students at R2i2 are encouraged to be creative, problem-solvers.  They work collaboratively with an eye towards  making positive change in their communities and beyond.  Students are encouraged to collaborate, tap into their creativity, lead, discovery opportunity, fail forward, and make a positive global impact.

Career Academy's Goal is for students to discover their passion and what they want to do with their future. Our goal is for students to either graduate with the Indiana College Core or graduate with an industry certification in a pathway. Students are engaged in projects in most, if not all, classes.

Through the Long-View Micro School experience and more generally in the participation in the culture of the school, learners develop initiative, adaptability, and curiosity; a bias toward taking intellectual risks and engaging fully in the learning process; and strength in critical listening, questioning, collaboration, and metacognition. Ultimately, Long-View strives to create learning experiences that cultivate intellectual, social, and behavioral autonomy and a durable identity as a lifelong learner.

NYOS is not your ordinary charter school.   Thats what our name stands for, and when you visit youll see why.   We are a single-site public charter school in Austin, serving sixteen hundred students PreK through 12.   We were founded by families in 1998 to serve the whole student, and that mission remains.   We are a school where students feel safe being and becoming who they are and want to be.   We support students on their individual pathway to college, career, or military readiness.   NYOS focuses on cultivating responsibility, confidence, compassion, and independence among all students.    We consistently receive the highest ratings from the Texas Education agency.   We consistently rank in the US News and World Report as a top high school nationwide and a top charter school nationwide.   The appeal of a NYOS education is strong; 2500 families are currently on our waitlist. 	 Here are the key features of our school design:  First, small class size.   NYOS classes are capped at 20.   Classes are often as small as 12 students, by design.   Second, seven hours of teacher-controlled time per week - almost a full day equivalent.  With this time, teachers plan, assess data, collaborate, and grow.   Third, two-year loops.  Students keep the same teacher for two years.   And finally, a year-round schedule sets a better pace for learning and makes the school year sustainable for staff.

The learning environment at Red Bridge is meant to support students in setting meaningful goals, making a plan to achieve them, accessing resources that will support their progress, having time to work and reflect, and having time for deep collaboration and connection with adults and peers.

DREAM Charter Schools implements a Grow the Whole Child model that promotes rigorous academics; athletics, health, and wellness; social emotional learning; and, family and community engagement. The four pillars of the model reinforce one another and the DREAM Schools curriculum supports students in fostering positive identities and developing the knowledge and skills necessary to participate in social action.  DREAMs key design elements are: - An innovative curriculum that emphasizes critical thinking and questioning - A co-teaching model that reduces the teacher-to-student ratio and integrates special needs students into the general school population - A robust data cycle that uses data to inform all aspects of teaching and learning - A whole child approach to teaching and learning that deeply integrates social emotional learning, health, wellness, music and the arts into the overall school program - An extended day and an extended year model that maximizes learning hours - An active family engagement program that fosters parent/guardian participation, leadership and advocacy - A focus on teacher motivation, development, and retention - A universal Pre-kindergarten program that ignites learning in children

Kids are seen and heard and treated as equals.  We often say to kids, ""we're built for you to find your thing and we can't start building your personalized framework until we know what's in your heart and mind"".  We want kids to explore, connect, engage, heal, and grow.  We're built around the idea of match quality which means that we want to instill a drive in children to never stop exploring until what they do for a living is also what makes them happy, gives them purpose, and is innately connected to their inherent aptitudes and what they believe in.

Students are empowered daily to own every aspect of their learning from developing their own schedule, their own projects, how they demonstrate mastery, and how quickly they move ahead. Our students lead the way at Launch and it helps them develop as leaders today and into the future.
An adult like work environment.  We frame The Village as ""adult practice."" Students get to practice being a college kid or adult worker but with support systems in place before they leave home.

school_desc_other_text: Our middle school is connected and in the same building as our high school, and operates independently with its own teachers.  I am the principal of both
school_description: A personalized mastery-based model where students work at their own pace. It places the students' personalized learning needs front and center and develops qualities in students that inspire and empower them to advocate for themselves, and it eliminates boundaries that could limit their success. Students receive richer opportunities through technology as a tool for deepening content knowledge and having access to content 24/7. Students are not penalized for non-academic aspects such as late or missing work. They do not earn zeroes; rather, the essential standards via rubrics, assessments, projects, platforms, and teacher mentoring guide and/or inform the student about what they need to do better through timely and meaningful feedback. Then, the student practices until they can do so. It also includes choices and varied pathways for students to achieve mastery and reassessment at all levels to achieve even higher levels of mastery.

At the Clement C. Moore School (PS13Q)we honor student voice and choice by encouraging the use of Computaional Thinking skills, LIM (Leader In Me)language, and fostering high expectations among all of our students. Students are expected to use their disverse backgrounds to flourish academically and socially.

Revolution School is a place-based, intentionally diverse, small, community-partnered school in Center City. Our mission and purpose is to serve culturally, linguistically, racially and socio-economically diverse families and their students in Philadelphia who benefit from a personalized, community connected and safe alternative to public education. We believe that every student is entitled to a high quality, engaging and equitable education. Our sliding scale tuition model provides access and affordability for all.

Schools were designed to maximize efficiency. Often students experience rigid schedules and space in addition to siloed subjects. This means that schools cannot address meaningful community problems, individuals' needs cannot be met, and schools are often unable to include students in authentic decisions. Teachers often work hard to make learning relevant and personalized, but are constrained in this model. This leads to negative outcomes, disengagement, and students acting out.  To meet the diverse needs and aspirations of all students, Exploration High School is designed for flexibility, focused on four areas: time, space, roles, and goals. Having a more flexible schedule allows students to spend time in pursuit of mastery, self-discovery, and service. We learn from experts in the community and create a flexible space that tends towards collaboration. Students are Explorers who design their unique learning pathway with guidance, structure, and support.
